content: Corrected "Natural intervals" to include A as "perfect prime", it seems to be consistent with the tests.

If I understand well, you can never have a perfect prime nor diminished prime ?
You also never tests X X-, is it a diminished octave ?
I corrected loop N read from:string(2) to:string(2) to loop N read from:word(2) to:word(2)

To do list:
[FIXED] "alteration" doesn't seem to be in common use in English. But "accidental" would be incorrect here. Think of something, but the problem size limitation hits hard...
[PENDING] the cases are currently all ordered the same. Which is fine for tests, but they ought to be shuffled in the validators before final publication

Mystery keys, for memory:
- G Major
- B Major
- Dâ™­ Major
- A Minor
- F Minor
- C Minor
- C

There can't be a perfect prime in the tests. (see Arglanir's question)

Could you be more specific as to what you changed?

Why this makes me uneasy:
- in the musical literature, the distinction is made between a perfect unison (A to A) and an augmented prime (A to A+).
- so in literature, perfect prime doesn't exist
- in this puzzle, there can be no perfect unison, only augmented primes
- so naming natural interval A to A a perfect prime makes sense in neither.

But it would be even more confusing to include the semantically correct perfect unison in the list instead, since those are out of bounds to the puzzle.

So best to not include it at all IMHO (the "prime" name is in the list, and it's covered in the tests if there's really a need)

Thing is that there is no indication whatsoever as to where "prime" starts from so that a modification can be applied. For what a musical ignorant like me knows, it might be augmented or dimished in its "starting" state. 

The spirit of the modification was to convey this; you might want to phrase things differently to provide the same information of course (e.g. say that "Additionally, A+ is an augmented prime").

I see your point. Thank you.

I'll try and think of something.

I'd expect all of those to be excluded by the "smallest strictly rising interval between the two pitches" constraint.
So:
- perfect prime -> not strictly rising, would be perfect octave
- diminished prime -> whooooooa there, that's theoretically not even rising.
- augmented octave -> nope, the augmented prime is smaller
- yes, X to X- would be a diminished octave, though I'm not sure there actually is one in there. I've tried to keep it "common practice".
